  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






You’ve seen the war 
      on the news, but have you seen it at home?  For Sunday’s entire hour 
      this Memorial Day weekend, 60 Minutes shows you an 
      intimate view of the home front as well as an intimate view of the 
      battlefront when correspondent 
      Scott Pelley and 60 Minutes cameras spend 
      nearly two years with a National Guard battalion serving in Iraq and 
      their families at home. "Fathers, Sons and Brothers" is a revealing and 
      emotional chronicle of the 1st Battalion, 133rd Infantry of the 
      Iowa National Guard, a storied unit dating to the Civil War. It follows 
      the farmers, mechanics, students, plumbers, electricians—everyday 
      Iowans—who left loved ones behind for the call to duty. It's also about 
      the wives, mothers and children of those citizen soldiers waiting for 
      their loved ones to return.   
 
Both of Tonya Rosol’s twin 
      sons serve, one stateside in officer school and the other in 
      Iraq. "For a mother to 
      send her child into harm’s way is unnatural," says Rosol. "There are 
      100,000-plus mothers who are doing this…It’s the hardest thing I have ever 
      done."
 
In the first part of this 
      story, 60 Minutes captures the 
      beginning of the soldiers’ journey, full of hope and determination. Part 
      two offers the day-to-day realities and sacrifices of life at war, with 
      its close calls and inevitable casualties, and then the anticipation of 
      going home. The disappointment and anger is palpable in part three, as 
      soldiers and families learn their tour will be extended as part of the 
      president’s troop surge. In part four, frustration sets in as families 
      grapple with the unfairness of part-time soldiers forced into a long-term 
      sacrifice, while some battle-hardened soldiers’ attitudes toward their 
      mission has changed
 
This Memorial Day weekend, the 
      1st Battalion of the 133rd Infantry is still in 
      Iraq.  Their spouses, 
      children, siblings, relatives and neighbors are still waiting for their 
      return.
 
Sunday, May 27, at 7 
      p.m. ET/PT.
